sols_html:
We can show that the sequence \({b_n}\) is Cauchy. Let \(\epsilon > 0\), then if n and m are larger than \(1/(2\epsilon)\) (that’s the value of N, you can see from the argument below how we might have guessed it), then if m \(\geq\) n, we have that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle | b_m - b_n | < \frac{1}{m+n} \leq \frac{1}{2n} < \epsilon\end{aligned}\]

And since Cauchy sequences of real numbers are always convergent, we know that the limit of this sequence exists.

statement_html:
Suppose that \(\{ b_n \}\) is a sequence that satisfies

\[\begin{aligned} |b_m-b_n| < \frac{1}{m+n} \quad\text{for all }m,n \in \mathbb{N}.\end{aligned}\]

Prove that

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{n \to \infty} b_n\end{aligned}\]

exists.
